title: Headlines: 16/07/07 - 20/07/07
name: Headlines: 16/07/07 - 20/07/07
description:
A Map by Leaderonline

The week's headlines from the Evening Leader

properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline

properties.name: 16/07/07 - Nazi symbol burnt into golf course
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline Yobs who scorched a 20ft by 20ft swatiska on one of the greens at Flint Golf Club have been branded as mindless vandals. Shocked club captain Bryan Strong said the damage was discovered by the greenkeeper early on Saturday morning and shockwaves spread as members came to see what had happened. Speaking from his motor sales business on Chester Street, Flint, Mr Strong said: "It\'s appalling. I can\'t imagine why anyone would do this. It\'s looks like the grass has been burned off with white spirit and they\'ve left the mark of a swastika. "I can only imagine it might be done out of envy, but we as a club welcome young members. We have 80 juniors who we subsidise. No other North Wales club does more than we do." Mr Strong, who confirmed that the police had been informed, said the club was still assessing the damage. He asked that anyone who may have seen anything suspicious should inform the police. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3033295

properties.name: 16/07/07 - Polish ambassador on visit to town
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE Polish ambassador visited Wrexham to speak to students about why they came to the UK to study and work. Barbara Tuge-Erecin\'ska officially opened the gap personnel Training Suite in Charles Street, Wrexham. The suite has been launched as a partnership between the company and Yale College to provide basic skills training, IT and Learndirect courses to workers in the area. This is assisted with funding from the Welsh Assembly Government. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3032179

properties.name: 16/07/07 - Soccer team all kitted out for the Eisteddfod
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline The under-11 football team from Ysgol Glanrafon, Mold, will be sporting a brand new kit when they take part in the school knockout tournament at the National Eisteddfod, thanks to the support of Principality. The Welsh building society donated £240 towards a much-needed strip for the team, and Amanda Davies, from Principality in Mold, said: "We are delighted that we were able to support Ysgol Glanrafon through our branch sponsorship scheme. It\'s great to see the children rewarded for their hard work – and really enjoying having great fun playing football. We hope that their new kits will give them a boost of confidence for the competition this summer." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3033079

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Council criticised over care of vulnerable youngsters
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA REPORT into children\'s social services in Wrexham has criticised the county\'s arrangements for protecting vulnerable children. In a report to be presented to the children and young people\'s scrutiny committee tomorrow, councillors will be told an inspection carried out by the Care & Social Services Inspectorate Wales found "significant gaps" in the service offered, particularly in the protection of children identified as at risk. Although the inspectors found many examples of good practice in children\'s social services, they pointed to child protection as an area of concern, and highlighted the arrangements surrounding case conferences as being in need of changes. The inspectors\' report says that although Wrexham has comparatively few children on the child protection register, the numbers had increased, with a particularly sharp rise at the end of last year. It says: "When a child is on the register for child protection, plans are not sufficiently specific or outcome-focused, and do not generally indicate what changes need to occur, who is responsible for ensuring change, within what timescale, and what contingency plans are in place. Strengths and weaknesses in the family are not routinely noted, and there is no risk analysis. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3033479

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Golf club's £80,000 repair bill over nazi symbol
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A GIANT Nazi symbol scorched into a golf green could land the club with a total repair bill of £80,000. Flint Golf Club is concerned the massive bill to repair the vandalism to four of their greens could ruin the club. On Sunday morning, greenkeeper Steven Roberts discovered a 20ft by 20ft swastika scorched into the course\'s first green, with what is believed to be petrol or diesel. The green was recently ranked the best in Wales by the Welsh Golfing Union and the course has won plaudits across the UK. Three other greens have also been targeted in the attack. Club captain Bryan Strong says each green could cost about £20,000 to repair. He said: "We are going to try and wash it out using chemicals and then re-seed it, which will take ages. "Our big concern is it\'s gone down into the roots and if that\'s the case we have a major problem. "It\'s £20,000 just for one green and I don\'t know where we are going to find that money, we\'re just a small club." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3035388

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Manhunt after Chester woman is doused in petrol
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE are hunting for a man who threw two litres of petrol over his former partner in Chester last night. It\'s claimed the woman, of Brentwood Road, Blacon, had petrol poured over her head and in her eyes, by her former partner, a 22-year-old man. Chester Fire Station Blue Watch Firefighter Jim Payne said on arrival at 7.15pm, the female was in a highly distressed state, standing in her kitchen. He said: "The 25-year-old woman had petrol covering her body. This could have been fatal if any ignition source had gone near her. It was a lucky escape for her." Five firefighters went into the kitchen and used tap water to douse the petrol off her skin. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3036189

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Rapist's horrific attack on widow, 74
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA \'monster\' who attacked and raped a pensioner in her own home has today been locked up indefinitely. Speaking after defendant Keith Sharpe, 34, was sentenced for the offences against a 74-year-old Wrexham woman, DI Jeremy Vaughan said: "This was a despicable and cowardly attack on a 74-year-old lady at her home address. "The resilience and true grit shown by this lady throughout the investigation has played no small part in the guilty plea and the subsequent sentence that Sharpe has now received. "The 74-year-old lady described how this incident ruined her life and she will continue to receive the support of the police Family Liaison Officer in order to try to begin to re-build her life and the long healing process ahead." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3035247

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Spruce yourselves up in time for Eisteddfod plea by MP
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineHOUSEHOLDERS in Flintshire are being asked to ensure their homes look pristine in time for next month\'s National Eisteddfod. The festival, which runs from August 4-11, on the Pentrehobyn Estate, Mold, is likely to attract more than 100,000 visitors and give the county\'s tourism industry a massive boost. And Alyn and Deeside MP Mark Tami wants all residents, and businesses, to ensure their homes and properties are blooming when it starts. Mr Tami also wants the county\'s streets to be clean and litter-free to create a good impression on those who visit Flintshire during the week. He said every effort should be made to showcase the county during the cultural celebrations. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3034798

properties.name: 18/07/07 - Animal welfare award for city zoo
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTV VET Steve Leonard took time out to present a prestigious animal welfare award to Chester Zoo. The presenter of numerous shows, including Vets in Practice, Ultimate Killers and Orangutan Diaries, yesterday presented a team from the zoo and Durham University with the coveted Universities Federation for Animal Welfare Wild Animal Welfare Award, for a study which helped to reduce stress levels of the zoo\'s mandrills. The study discovered that planting a barrier of shrubs between the mandrills\' enclosure and the visitors\' viewing area improved the mandrills\' behaviour. Zoo research officer Dr Sonya Hill, who specialises in primate behaviour and welfare, was helped by two students, Riccardo Pansini and Jessica Hargreaves, from Durham University, where they were supervised by Dr Jan de Ruiter. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3039115

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: 'Use English first' call at rail stations
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM MP Ian Lucas has called for announcements at train stations to be made in English first. Mr Lucas is among seven Labour MPs to sign House of Commons motion, calling on a review of the current policy. The group want announcements in Welsh towns and cities with low numbers of Welsh speakers to be made in English first, claiming the current practice of using Welsh first causes confusion. The motion says the group "wholly support" the policy of bilingual announcements, but believe that "it would be far more sensible and far more convenient for passengers, whether regular commuters or local visitors, if announcements at each station were made first in the language used by the majority of the local population". Mr Lucas, who travels frequently by train and is not a Welsh speaker, said English should be used first in Wrexham and pointed out that the numbers of people staying in the area from abroad, who may speak English but not Welsh, was also a factor. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3038211

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Calls for booze to be banned from streets
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM could become only the second place in the UK to enforce a county-wide ban on boozing in public places. It would also become the first authority in Wales to make the move if calls from an opposition leader on the council are carried out. Cllr Neil Rogers said residents in the town and the surrounding villages were "sick and tired" of having to put up with drunken yobs consuming vast amounts of alcohol on the streets and in parks. The councillor told yesterday\'s executive board meeting, during a debate on a new anti-social behaviour strategy, that Wrexham should be the first authority in Wales, and only the second in Britain, to introduce a total ban on boozing in all public places. Cllr Rogers said: "Every Friday and Saturday night, in every community in Wrexham borough, there is alcohol being consumed by young children. It is a concern which keeps coming up at every community council meeting and every residents\' meeting. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3038495

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: I'll have to leave Wales for vital cancer treatment
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A MUM-of-two, struck down by cancer, has been denied vital treatment – because she lives in Wales. Samantha Cousins, 34, of Victoria Avenue, Johnstown, has been recommended for a bone marrow transplant as part of her two-year battle with Hodgkin\'s disease. She has been treated at Manchester\'s specialist Christie\'s Hospital, where consultant Dr Adrian Bloor recommended she be given the treatment. But because she lives in Wales, funding for Samantha\'s treatment has to come from Health Commission Wales, which blocked it, leaving her feeling she has been a victim of a "postcode lottery". Now, she says she may be driven to move from Wales to find somewhere where her transplant will be funded. She said: "I have been having chemotherapy for two years. The doctors said they would not be putting me forward for me to have the transplant if I did not need it, and if it would not help. "My treatment is working, and I need this as the next stage, but in the end it all comes down to the money." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3038216

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Parents in playground sewage fury
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline  PARENTS have banned their children from using a playground, claiming it is swimming in sewage and has made the youngsters ill. The council-run playing fields were used by about 30 children from Deva Avenue, Bryn y Coed and the bottom of Bryn Mawr Road on Holywell\'s Strand estate. Now the playground is empty as parents claim their children have suffered stomach pains, sickness and diarrhoea after playing there. Residents say a basketball court in the park is drowned in a murky mess, smelling of sewage, along with dangerous debris, including planks of wood, a sharp-edged broken plastic container and an old car radio. Deva Avenue resident, Veronica Jones, who looks after her three-year-old nephew Thomas Lee, said: "A lot of kids on this avenue all go and play there. It\'s so close we feel safe letting them play there because we can look over the hedge and keep an eye out. "I let Thomas go and he came back covered in sewage, so I don\'t let him go anymore. All the kids are complaining of stomach aches and sickness and diarrhoea, one girl went to hospital a couple of weeks ago." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3040104

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Plans to scrap Glass Slug are on target
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineNEGOTIATIONS to kill off Chester\'s Glass Slug council offices are on track, say leading councillors. Conservative Town Hall rulers, who swept to power in May on a promise of doing away with proposed new city council offices, say discussions with the proposed developer ING are proceeding according to plan. Deputy council leader, Cllr Stephen Mosley, said: "Negotiations have begun and everything is proceeding as expected. As you would expect, we are prevented from saying too much for legal reasons. "The Glass Slug is a small part of a very complicated contract, but what has become apparent is that the rising costs of the scheme were threatening the whole plan to regenerate the city centre. "We have found and are continuing to find the developer ING very helpful, and we are confident of a deal that will be beneficial to the city, its taxpayers and its future prosperity. "It was never right to spend that sort of money on plush offices for Councillors." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3039175

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Campaign fails to save school with 13 pupils
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline RESIDENTS have lost the struggle to save their village\'s only school and will watch helplessly when the doors finally close after 120 years. After months of petitioning and lobbying local representatives, the community of Rhydymwyn received the response it had dreaded – Ysgol y Ddol is to shut for good at the end of term. Flintshire Council claim they made the decision because pupil numbers had halved, to just 13, in five years. Headteacher Gwyn Lloyd-Jones said it means the "heart of the village is being ripped out". He said: "We have lost a pub in the past eight years, and the post office, and now the community is losing its school." Flintshire Council\'s executive member for education, Cllr Chris Bithell, said Ysgol y Ddol is closing because "numbers have declined to such an extent the school is not really viable any more." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3043525

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Museum revamp backed
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline COUNCILLORS have backed a £2.1 million revamp of Wrexham Museum, saying it will be a major boost to the town\'s cultural heritage. The renovation will make the facility more family friendly and popular, Wrexham Council\'s executive board meeting heard. Plans include a more inviting forecourt with better signs and more interactive and community-focused displays on the ground floor. A report said the estimate cost of the project is £2.1 million. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3040706

properties.name: 19/07/07 - River promenade dream becomes a reality after 10 years
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA 10-YEAR dream of riverside link between Chester and Flintshire is now a reality. The River Dee was the focus of lively celebrations as the Lord Mayor and Lady Mayoress of Chester, Cllr Jim Latham and his wife Hilary, officially opened the multi-million pound Riverside Promenade. The development, which has taken three years to complete, has been an aspiration of Chester City Council for a decade. Schoolchildren, residents and dignitaries came together to mark the official opening of e and enjoy parts of the River Dee which were previously inaccessible. Entertainment from a band and host of colourful characters added to the occasion and set out to bring the river\'s unique history to life. About 90 pupils from Victoria County Infant and St Thomas of Canterbury Junior schools joined Cllr Latham as the first people to officially walk the promenade. The journey ended at Chester\'s Old Port, where all of the children received certificates to mark their achievement. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3041117

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Swimmers' Dee-lightful fundraiser
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO Chester men have raised £500 through a sponsored swim in the River Dee. Tim Clifton, of Walter Street, Newtown, and Steve Walker, of Boughton Heath, braved the waters in a gruelling 5.5km swim from Eccleston to the Grosvenor Rowing Club, on The Groves. Tim, a teacher at Boughton Heath Primary School, Chester, said: "It took about an hour and 10 minutes to do, it was a bit quicker than we thought because the flow was with us. "We were probably one of the only people praying for rain because it meant it wasn\'t as hard." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3041113

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Woman hurt in gas blast
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN is being treated for burns after a gas explosion at her home. Fire crews and paradmedics were called to the scene of the explosion in Lixwm, near Holywell, at 6pm yesterday. It believed the blast was caused by the gas being left on or leaking in the day. When the woman returned, she inadvertently ingnited the fumes, causing an explosion of such force it shattered windows and blew a hole in the roof. Ambulance crews took the victim to Whiston Hospital, Merseyside, where she is now undergoing treatment for burns to the face and arms. A North Wales Fire and Rescue service spokesman said: "The gas had been left on all day and somehow exploded, leaving the lady with burns to her arms and face." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3043376

properties.name: 20/07/07 - BREAKING NEWS: Two test positive in TB school
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A CHILD and one member of staff have had \'positive readings\' after being screened for TB. The National Public Health Service for Wales has just announced the child and the member of staff, both at Holywell High School, have been referred for further tests after the result. The screening comes after a teacher at the school was diagnosed with TB in June, prompting all those who came into close proximity with the teacher to be tested. Following a screening last week, 208 children and ten members of staff have been given the all clear. One child and one member of staff had positive readings and have been referred for further tests. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3047819

properties.name: 20/07/07 - Maelor set for £5 million A&E revamp
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM Maelor Hospital is to spend £5 million in a bid to tackle the massive rise in the number of people being treated in its A&E unit. Work will start tomorrow with the temporary closure of two wards, with further work planned for September and October. Hospital bosses say that in recent years, the number of casualties coming in has risen rapidly, and in 2006/07 about 65,000 people were seen in a unit originally designed for half that number. Corporate support manager Andrew Scotson said: "Inevitably, this sometimes leads to congestion and patients having to put up with long waits for treatment. "However, developments over the next two years will ensure that people coming into the department are assessed on arrival and directed straight to the most appropriate type of care. "So that this can happen, the local GP out-of-hours service will move onto the Maelor Hospital site, the A&E department will be extended, and new short-stay assessment areas will be created where patients can be looked after and kept under observation while tests are carried out." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3047555

properties.name: 20/07/07 - Royal couple meet the crowds on city visit
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSTAFF and students waved Union Jack flags in a show of patriotism as the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall arrived at the University of Chester. The Earl and Countess of Chester, Charles and Camilla, were greeted in the sunshine as they arrived for a showcase of schemes run by the Prince\'s Trust and the university\'s volunteering work, before attending a ceremony for Charles to receive an Honorary Degree. English language students from Italy, staying on campus during the summer, waved Italian flags alongside Union Jack flags and the couple spent several minutes shaking hands and speaking to the young people. Stephanie Bath, founder of Posh Pickles and Preserves and Posh Bites delicatessen in Frodsham, set up through funding from the Prince\'s Trust. "It was really exciting to meet Prince Charles. He was really nice and so was Camilla," she said. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3047637
